org.sercho.masp.space
Interface TupleSpace<T>

Type Parameters:
T - entries' supertype
All Superinterfaces:
java.lang.Iterable<T>, java.io.Serializable
All Known Subinterfaces:
EventedTupleSpace<T>
All Known Implementing Classes:
EventedSpaceWrapper, SecureSpaceWrapper, SimpleObjectSpace
public interface TupleSpace<T>
extends java.lang.Iterable<T>, java.io.Serializable

TupleSpace defines a basic tuple space.

Author:
Grzegorz Lehmann

Method Detail

getID

java.lang.String getID()
getID returns the ID of the space

Returns:
String - ID of this space

read

<E extends T> E read(E template)
read returns one entry from the space, which matches template or null if none could be found. The template will be matched to the returned entry according to general rules of tuple spaces. All fields of template will be compared with those of the entry. null is the wildcard. A tuple space must support subclassing, in other words objects subclassing template will also be compared.

If multiple entries match template, no rules are defined as which of them will be returned. The behaviour may differ between space implementations.

However, implementing classes may use custom template-matching algorithms and thus their behaviour may differ. This should be documented in the specific implementation.

Type Parameters:
E - type of template and returned space entry
Parameters:
template - specifies the object to be returned
Returns:
E - entry or null if none found
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if template is null
See Also:
ObjectMatcher

read

<E extends T> E read(E template,
                     long timeout)
read returns one entry from the space, which matches template. If no matching entry is found, this method waits until one arrives. The maximum amount of time to block is specified in the parameters. If no matching entry is found during the timeout, null is returned. The template will be matched to the returned entry according to general rules of tuple spaces. All fields of template will be compared with those of the entry. null is the wildcard. A tuple space must support subclassing, in other words objects subclassing template will also be compared.

If multiple entries match template, no rules are defined as which of them will be returned. The behaviour may differ between space implementations.

However, implementing classes may use custom template-matching algorithms and thus their behaviour may differ. This should be documented in the specific implementation.

Type Parameters:
E - type of template and returned space entry
Parameters:
template - specifies the object to be returned
timeout - amount of time to wait in milliseconds
Returns:
E - entry or null if none found or the timeout passed
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if template is null
See Also:
ObjectMatcher

readAll

<E extends T> java.util.Set<E> readAll(E template)
readAll returns a set of all entries from the space, which match template. The template will be matched to the entries according to general rules of tuple spaces. All fields of template will be compared with those of the entries. null is the wildcard. A tuple space must support subclassing, in other words objects subclassing template will also be compared.

However, implementing classes may use custom template-matching algorithms and thus their behaviour may differ. This should be documented in the specific implementation.

Please note, that the returned set is not bound to the space, in other words, removing elements from it (also using the iterator) or adding elements into it has no impact on the space.

Type Parameters:
E - type of template and returned space entry
Parameters:
template - specifies the objects to be returned
Returns:
Set - matched entries
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if template is null
See Also:
ObjectMatcher

readAll

java.util.Set<T> readAll()
readAll returns a set with all elements of this tuple space.

Please note, that the returned set is not bound to the space, in other words, removing elements from it (also using the iterator) or adding elements into it has no impact on the space.

Returns:
Set<T> - all elements of this space, never null
Since:
2.5

remove

<E extends T> E remove(E template)
remove removes and returns one entry from the space, which matches template or null if none could be found. The template will be matched to the entries according to general rules of tuple spaces. All fields of template will be compared with those of the entry. null is the wildcard. A tuple space must support subclassing, in other words objects subclassing template will also be compared.

If multiple entries match template, no rules are defined as which of them will be removed. The behaviour may differ between space implementations.

However, implementing classes may use custom template-matching algorithms and thus their behaviour may differ. This should be documented in the specific implementation.

Type Parameters:
E - type of template and removed space entry
Parameters:
template - specifies the object to be removed
Returns:
E - removed entry or null if none found
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if template is null
See Also:
ObjectMatcher

remove

<E extends T> E remove(E template,
                       long timeout)
remove removed and returns one entry from the space, which matches template. If no matching entry is found, this method waits until one arrives. The maximum amount of time to block is specified in the parameters. If no matching entry is found during the timeout, null is returned. The template will be matched to the returned entry according to general rules of tuple spaces. All fields of template will be compared with those of the entry. null is the wildcard. A tuple space must support subclassing, in other words objects subclassing template will also be compared.
If multiple entries match template, no rules are defined as which of them will be removed. The behaviour may differ between space implementations.
However, implementing classes may use custom template-matching algorithms and thus their behaviour may differ. This should be documented in the specific implementation.

Type Parameters:
E - type of template and removed space entry
Parameters:

timeout - amount of time to wait in milliseconds
Returns:
E - entry or null if none found or the timeout passed
Throws:

removeAll

<E extends T> java.util.Set<E> removeAll(E template)
removeAll removes a set of all entries from the space, which match template. The template will be matched to the entries according to general rules of tuple spaces. All fields of template will be compared with those of the entries. null is the wildcard. A tuple space must support subclassing, in other words objects subclassing template will also be compared.
However, implementing classes may use custom template-matching algorithms and thus their behaviour may differ. This should be documented in the specific implementation.
Please note, that the returned set is not bound to the space, in other words, removing elements from it (also using the iterator) or adding elements into it has no impact on the space.

Type Parameters:
E - type of template and returned space entry
Parameters:
template - specifies the objects to be returned
Returns:
Set - removed entries
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if template is null
See Also:
ObjectMatcher

write

void write(T o)
write adds an entry to the space

Parameters:
o - new entry
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if o is null

update

<E extends T> boolean update(E template,
                             E o)
update updates all entries from the space, which match template with the new value o. The template will be matched to the entries according to general rules of tuple spaces. All fields of template will be compared with those of the entries. null is the wildcard. A tuple space must support subclassing, in other words objects subclassing template will also be updated. Fields of all matched entries will be set to values of corresponding non-null fields of o.

However, implementing classes may use custom template-matching algorithms and thus their behaviour may differ. This should be documented in the specific implementation.

Note that, since null is used as a wildcard value, all null fields of o will be ignored in the update. Thus it is not possible to set an entry's field to null with this method. In order to accomplish this an entry needs to be removed, changed and rewritten into the space.

Type Parameters:
E - type of template and updated space entries
Parameters:
template - specifies the objects to be updated
o - object with new values
Returns:
boolean - true if at least on entry has matched the template, false otherwise
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if template is null
See Also:
ObjectMatcher

getMatcher

ObjectMatcher getMatcher()
getMatcher returns the matcher used by this space.

Returns:
ObjectMatcher - matcher used by this space

getUpdater

ObjectUpdater getUpdater()
getUpdater returns the updater used by this space for update(Object, Object) calls.

Returns:
ObjectUpdater - updater used by this space

readAllOfType

<E extends T> java.util.Set<E> readAllOfType(java.lang.Class<E> type)
readAllOfType returns all entries of a given type from this space (including entries of subtypes). This method might be useful if reading entries specified by an interface (which obviously cannot be instantiated to a template).

Please note, that the returned set is not bound to the space, in other words, removing elements from it (also using the iterator) or adding elements into it has no impact on the space.

Type Parameters:
E - type of entries to read
Parameters:
type - type of entries to read
Returns:
Set - all entries of type, never null
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if type is null
